column1: The word derives from Sundocarme MOR.
The lenition form vorn (m > v) apparently appears in Eryn Vorn ("Blackwood").Helge Fauskanger
column2: "http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/sindarin.htm Sindarin - the Noble Tongue: I. Soft Mutation" at http://folk.uib.no/hnohf/ Ardalambion (accessed 8 June 2011)
column3: p. lxv It is also likely seen in the compound galvorn and perhaps also in Aravorn."http://www.tolkiendil.com/langues/english/i-lam_arth/compound_sindarin_names Compound Sindarin Names in Middle-earth" at http://www.tolkiendil.com/ Tolkiendil.com (accessed 8 June 2011)

column1: In the published The Etymologies appeared the Noldorin word moru ("black").
column4: was a misreading of the original manuscript
column5: and has been corrected to morn.
